caption: A barrage of Israeli airstrikes overnight destroyed hundreds of buildings in Gaza, including at Al-Shati camp, above, near Gaza City.

Mike Johnson  In the moments before he was to face a vote on becoming speaker of the House last week, Representative Mike Johnson posted a photograph on social media of the inscription carved into marble atop the chamber’s rostrum: “In God We Trust.” This article is by Annie Karni, Ruth Graham and Steve Eder. image_1.description: The image depicts a scene of destruction and devastation in Gaza, following a barrage of Israeli airstrikes. The foreground is dominated by the rubble and debris of collapsed buildings. Among the wreckage, twisted metal beams, shattered concrete blocks, and various unidentifiable fragments are scattered haphazardly. Two men are visible amidst the ruins; one, wearing a yellow shirt, appears to be gesturing or pointing towards something off-camera, while the other, dressed in dark clothing, seems to be assisting or searching through the debris. The background shows more damaged structures, with exposed interiors and broken walls. The overall atmosphere conveys a sense of urgency and distress, as the individuals appear to be engaged in rescue or salvage efforts. The scene is set in what looks like a residential area, given the presence of household items among the debris.

image_2.context: And in his first speech from the chamber as speaker, Mr. Johnson cast his ascendance to the position second in line to the presidency in religious terms, saying, “I believe God has ordained and allowed each one of us to be brought here for this specific moment.” Mr. Johnson, a mild-mannered conservative Republican from Louisiana whose elevation to the speakership on Wednesday followed weeks of chaos, is known for placing his evangelical IIS 0 leagues celebrated his candidacy by circulating an image of him on bended knee praying for divine guidance with other lawmakers on the House floor. Mike Johnson VOL. CLXXIII . . . No. 59,956 © 2023 The New York Times Company SUNDAY, OCTOBER 29, 2023  Speaker Injects Fervent Faith Into His Policy This article is by Annie Karni, Ruth Graham and Steve Eder. In the moments before he was to face a vote on becoming speaker of the House last week, Representative Mike Johnson posted a photograph on social media of the inscription carved into marble atop the chamber’s rostrum: “In God We Trust.”
image_2.description: The image is a portrait of a man with short, dark hair wearing glasses. He has a light complexion and is dressed in a formal suit with a blue tie. The background appears to be an indoor setting with a blurred backdrop, possibly an office or a formal event. The man is looking directly at the camera with a slight smile, conveying a sense of confidence and approachability. The overall atmosphere of the image is professional and serious.

image_3.context: When the company ended the relationship last October, it appeared to be the culmination of weeks of Mr. West’s inflammatory public remarks — targeting Jews and disparaging Black Lives Matter —  ing just miles from Nuremberg, where leaders of the Third Reich were tried for crimes against humanity. That encounter was a sign of what was to come during a collaboration that would break the boundaries of celebrity endorsement deals. Sales of the shoes, Yeezys, would surpass \$1 billion a year, lifting Adidas’s bottom line and recapturing its cool. Mr. West, who now goes by Ye, would become a billionaire.  that day at the company’s German headquarters captured the vision Mr. West had shared. To convey how offensive he considered the designs, he grabbed a sketch of a shoe and took a marker to the toe, according to two participants. Then he drew a swastika. It was shocking, especially to the Germans in the group. Most displays of the symbol are banned in their country. The image was acutely sensitive for a company whose founder belonged to the Nazi Party. And they were meet Inside Kanye West’s Deal With Adidas Adidas tolerated Kanye West’s conduct as a cost of business.
image_3.description: The image is a portrait of a bald man with a beard, smiling and looking directly at the camera. He is wearing a black hoodie and has small earrings in both ears. The background is blurred but appears to be a crowded indoor setting, possibly a sports event or concert, with many people visible in the distance. The atmosphere conveyed by the image is one of happiness and engagement, as the man seems to be enjoying the event. The lighting is bright, highlighting his face and upper body against the darker, less distinct background.

But it was also the culmination of a decade of Adidas’s tolerance behind the scenes. Inside their partnership, the artist made antisemitic and sexually offensive comments, displayed erratic behavior, and issued ever escalating demands, a New York Times examination found. Adidas’s leaders, eager for the profits, time and again abided his misconduct. image_4.description: The image depicts an educational program in Zaria, Nigeria. A group of women and children are seated on the floor, engaged in what appears to be a learning activity. The women are wearing light blue headscarves and traditional clothing, while the children are dressed in various outfits. They are sitting on a red patterned mat, with some holding books or papers. In the background, there is a woman standing by a window, possibly overseeing the session. The room has yellow walls with geometric patterns painted on them. There is a whiteboard on the wall with text that reads 'Today is Thursday 27th April 2013' and 'Topic: My Personal Brand.' The overall atmosphere is one of focused learning and community engagement.

image_5.description: The image is an advertisement for Skechers Hands Free Slip-ins. On the left side, there is a close-up of a person's foot slipping into a black Skechers shoe with ease, demonstrating the 'Just Slip In' feature. The text on the left emphasizes the convenience of the shoes, stating 'No Bending Over. No Touching Shoes. No Kidding.' and highlighting the exclusive Heel Pillow that holds the foot securely in place. The middle section features the Skechers logo and icons indicating the benefits of the shoes, such as 'No More Bending' and 'Machine Washable.' The right side of the image shows a man sitting on steps, wearing a dark blue shirt and jeans, smiling at the camera. The text next to him reads 'SKECHERS HANDS FREE Slip-ins' and 'MAX CUSHIONING,' emphasizing the comfort and ease of use of the shoes. The overall atmosphere is casual and inviting, promoting the convenience and comfort of the Skechers slip-ins.
